Award.AwardTitle: Analyzing Atmospheric Warming and Environmental Changes from High-Altitude Ice Cores

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Historical evidence indicates that climate has contributed to the rise and fall of civilizations. The evidence also suggests that early human activities, such as land-use changes and biomass degradation, may have impacted climate. While current scientific evidence indicates that human-emitted greenhouse gases are contributing to the increase in temperatures across the globe, insights into short-term regional changes are much more ambiguous. This research project will focus on the reciprocal influence between atmospheric warming and environmental changes in ecosystems and human society from the coldest time interval of the Holocene (a period known as "the Little Ice Age") to the current warm period. The project will provide new perspectives about the synergies between atmospheric pollution and climate change, especially at higher elevations where rapid glacial melting often occurs. The insights from this project will advance basic understanding about relationships between the impacts of human-induced atmospheric pollution on climate as well as factors that may lead to both the amplification of atmospheric warming and the suppression of atmospheric temperatures. Project results will help guide policy makers, governmental agencies, and resource administrators in assessing appropriate courses of action. This project also will strengthen international research collaborations among U.S. and European scientists and institutions.

Four ice cores retrieved from the ice field atop Mt. Ortles, the highest mountain in South Tyrol, Italy, reveal records of at least four centuries of climatic and environmental history. These ice cores, which were extracted from one of the most rapidly warming and environmentally impacted areas in the world, offer a unique opportunity to investigate the interactions of strong regional environmental variations and wider-ranging global climatic patterns. Using isotopic analysis, trace elements ratios, mass spectrometry, and ion chromatography, the investigators will seek answers to three core questions: (1) Have temperatures increased at the high elevations over the past 400 years? (2) What is the relationship between larger levels of human-generated aerosols and increases in regional temperatures? (3) Do droughts and wet periods impact atmospheric particulate content? Project findings will provide new perspectives regarding the complex interactions among climate, human society, and ecosystems as well as their intricate linkages bound by the fluxes of mass and energy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2011 four ice cores were retrieved from the ice field atop Mt. Ortles (3905 m), the highest mountain of South Tyrol, in the Eastern Alps, Italy. We discovered that this glacier still contains ice below the freezing temperature and preserves a continuous record of the climatic and environmental histories of the Alps through the Holocene back to 7000 years ago during the Northern Hemisphere Climate Optimum. This drilling site is located in a very rapidly warming and environmentally impacted region of the world. In fact, this is one of the most industrialized and cultivated areas of the planet and several regions, such as the Po' Valley, are considered hot-spots of atmospheric emissions. The Mt. Ortles ice cores were used to study how regional environmental variations interact with superimposed climatic changes of global significance.

 

For this purpose, the Mt. Ortles ice cores were analyzed for various climatic and environmental proxies such as stable isotopes, major ions, trace elements, dust, pollen types, black carbon and other single particles. Remarkably, a novel radiocarbon methodology, combined with other well-established dating techniques and the precise synchronization with an array of Arctic ice core records, allows to obtain a chronology for an alpine ice core record that is extremely accurate back to at least 2000 years.

 

We found that a steady cooling characterized the Alps during the Holocene, with high temperatures during the Northern Hemisphere Climate Optimum and a  minimum during the Little Ice Age between the 16th and the 19th centuries. This cooling trend was accompanied by a general decrease in concentrations of various aerosol species that was suddenly interrupted by a rapid increase that peaked during the 60s and the 70s, mostly due to the advent of the most impacting part of the Anthropocene. The modern part of the ice core record also shows unequivocal evidence of the current atmospheric warming that, due to extensive current surface melting and meltwater percolation, is also affecting the resolution of the most recent part of the core (firn).

 

The Mt. Ortles ice cores also shows the history of atmospheric pollution of anthropogenic origin during the pre-industrial time when widespread mining operations impacted the atmosphere from Central Europe to the Arctic since at least the Roman period, 2000 years ago. Preliminary comparison of climatic and environmental variations suggests that independent temperature changes and human activities occurred during the pre-industrial time when social-economic factors were perhaps the main drivers of activities such as the extraction of minerals and smelting of metals (e.g. silver). During the 20th century many other human activities interacted synergistically with each other and are now the object of ongoing investigation.

 

This study is now serving as a source of information for policy makers to evaluate the current impact of climate change and aerosol species of anthropogenic origin on the alpine environment. This program was developed in the framework of the Ortles project initiative, an international collaboration between the Byrd Polar and Climate Research Center at The Ohio State University, the Province of Bolzano (Italy) and a number of collaborators from a various European Institutes from five countries (Italy, Switzerland, Russia, France and Austria). In USA, this project supported two female post-doctoral researchers and a young visiting scholar from South Tyrol in the analysis and study of the Mt. Ortles ice cores. An outreach program was developed and a new web site ( www.ortles.org ) presents the project to the international public.
